Technical Assistance Report
Project Number: 43333-01 
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
June 2010 
 
 
 
 
Improving  the  Implementation  of  Environmental 
Safeguards in Central and West Asia 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  COSO  –  Central Operations Services Office 
  CWRD  –  Central and West Asia Department

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION

Targeting classification  –  General intervention

Vice-President  X. Zhao, Operations 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  H. Du, Advisor, Office of the Director General, CWRD 
 
Team Leader  M. Kunzer, Senior Environment Specialist, CWRD 
Team Member  N. Djenchuraev, Environment Specialist, CWRD 
Team Member  Z. Abbas, National Environment Officer, CWRD 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The recently issued Safeguard Policy Statement (SPS) of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  introduces  a  new  emphasis  on  the  effective  implementation  of  environmental 
safeguards. 1  The  SPS  contains  a  number  of  operational  principles  which  include  the 
requirement to ensure that the measures identified during impact assessment are included in 
the project environmental management plan (EMP), and are implemented in agreement with the 
borrower. SPS also recognises that this is not always achieved at the project level and states 
that  "while  procedural  compliance  has  improved  over  time  the  substantive  aspects  of 
compliance—integration of findings and recommendations of environmental assessment into 
project design, borrower/client ownership of EMPs, and effective implementation of EMPs—
remain challenging".  
 
2.  Work undertaken by ADB's Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) has come to a 
similar view. A 2008 small-scale technical assistance (SSTA) on Improving the Implementation 
of Environmental Safeguards for ADB Projects in Central and West Asia (the region) undertook 
a  review  of  all  active  environment  category  A  projects  to  assess  how  effectively  these 
requirements  were  being  implemented. 2 The  review  highlighted  a  number  of  deficiencies 
preventing effective implementation. Foremost among the challenges is insufficient capacity in 
executing agencies to prepare, implement, and monitor the implementation of EMPs. The lack 
of  effective  implementation  means  that  there  is  a  credible  risk  that  projects  are  not  in 
compliance with the SPS. The proposed regional capacity development technical assistance (R-
CDTA) will strengthen the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies in the region to 
improve environmental management and monitoring. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Capacity assessments of the executing agencies in CWRD countries point to a severe 
shortage of environmental professionals with the environmental management skills necessary to 
effectively implement SPS requirements. There is a significant requirement for training of staff in 
the executing agencies. Training for safeguards is usually included as part of the scope of works 
assigned to design and supervision teams. This approach has a number of weaknesses, the 
most obvious being the poor performance of a number of existing projects, suggesting that 
delivery of training through this mechanism is not effective. Other weaknesses include the lack 
of consistency in what the training consists, high costs associated with the use of international 
consultants, failure to develop in-country capacity to deliver training, and the lack of any follow 
up capability once the training period has ended. 
 
4.  The lack of capacity and experience in the executing agencies leads to poor quality at 
entry  for  environmental  safeguard  requirements.  The  2008  TA  identified  key  areas  where 
support is required to improve performance and ensure quality at entry. Guidance is needed in a 
number of areas: 
 
(i)   The project administration memoranda (PAMs) issued to the executing agencies 
do  not  provide  sufficient  guidance  on  the  environmental  management  and 
monitoring requirements. There is a need for clear guidance on what is required, 
when it needs to be done and by whom. 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2009. Safeguard Policy Statement. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance for Improving the Implementation of Environmental Safeguards for ADB Projects 
in Central and West Asia. Manila (TA6457-REG for $150,000, approved on 24 April).

2   
(ii)   Environment  specialists  at  the  executing  agencies  have  little  experience  of 
drafting  conditions  of  contract  to  ensure  that  environmental  management 
requirements are included into the tender and contract documents. 
 
(iii)   The environment specialists also have limited knowledge in the preparation of 
site specific EMPs, this is often the case with the contractors as well. 
 
(iv)  The format and content of the biannual reports required from the projects has not 
been  defined.  This  leads  to  monitoring  reports  with  varying  content  and 
relevance. 
 
5.  Furthermore, the extent of monitoring activities should correspond to the environmental 
risks associated with a project. Therefore, there is a need to ensure that the environmental 
management of environment category A & B projects is regularly reviewed by a third party and 
that the capacity in each country is increased to conduct the reviews. 
 
6.  To address the lack of guidance for project executing agencies identified by the 2008 TA, 
knowledge  products  and  guidance  notes  were  prepared,  including  (i)  environmental 
management guidelines for the PAMs relating to the different lending modality, (ii) guidelines on 
how to include environmental management provisions in tenders, and (iii) contract documents 
and  handbooks  on  Environmental  Mitigation  Measures  for  Construction  and  Environmental 
Management for Construction Sites. These were then combined into a training course.  
 
7.  The training course was trialed with environmental specialists from a number executing 
and implementing agencies in Pakistan. An examination of different projects during construction 
has shown that these projects have similar types of environmental impacts requiring similar 
mitigation measures. This is due to the construction process having standard requirements that 
occur again and again across many different projects. For example, stripping of vegetation and 
earth moving is often one of the first activities to occur. The mitigation measures required to 
manage the impacts from these activities are therefore similar even though the projects are of 
very differing types.  
 
8.  There are also a number of measures that are widely accepted as the best method to 
deal  with  issues  such  as  dust  control,  stockpiling  materials,  protecting  watercourses  from 
erosion, and sediment. Therefore, it is possible to provide guidelines that will be applicable to 
most projects. The trial was successful and the approach found to be effective for a range of 
different projects.  
 
9.  The training course, however, needs to be further developed and refined for delivery 
across the region. This will increase the implementation and monitoring capacity of the project 
executing  and  implementing  agencies  to  successfully  implement  the  ADB  environmental 
safeguard requirements. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The expected impact will be that executing agencies effectively manage environmental 
projects supported by ADB, thereby improving their environmental sustainability. The expected

3
outcome  is  the  increased  capacity  of  staff  in  executing  agencies  to  undertake  effective 
environmental management and monitoring of ADB projects throughout the region. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Components 
 
a.  Training Course and Knowledge Products 
 
11.  The  knowledge  products  trialed  during  the  2008  TA  will  be  further  developed  and 
refined.  Of  particular  importance  is  the  development  of  a  range  of  case  studies  for  the 
Handbook on Environmental Management for Construction. The following knowledge products 
will be finalized: (i) environmental management inserts for the PAMs that cover the different 
lending modalities, (ii) guidelines on drafting environmental management clauses for tender 
documents  and  contracts,  (iii)  a  handbook  on  Environmental  Mitigation  Measures  for 
Construction, and (iv) a handbook on Environmental Management for Construction Sites. Once 
completed, the knowledge products need to be combined into a stand alone training program 
that can be delivered by multiple trainers in each CWRD country. 
 
b.  Training Course Delivery 
 
12.  The existing method of requiring the design and supervision consultants to undertake 
environmental safeguards training is ineffective because of higher costs, uneven quality, and 
unsustainability. The TA3 will take a different approach. A number of environmental service 
providers will be trained to deliver the training course in each country and will do so through an 
on-call basis.4 This approach will have a number of benefits such as ensuring that the type and 
content of training is consistent across all projects, providing a more cost effective approach by 
avoiding the costs of international consultants, developing an in-country training capability, 
providing an opportunity to undertake refresher training, and it will also allow contractors to 
commission the same training, at their cost. This component will also be supported by on-the-
job training if required. 
 
c.  Improved Project Monitoring 
 
13.  The  TA  will  also  support  the  establishment  of  a  web-based  tracking  system  for 
environmental  management.  All  projects  classified  as  environment  category  A  or  B  are 
expected to prepare six monthly monitoring reports for ADB and government authorities. A 
database will be established that will alert the project leader and safeguards team that the report 
is due and will record its delivery. The system will also function as a database for project 
environmental management documents. The system will allow staff from headquarters and 
resident missions to have access to a single source of information on project implementation 
performance.  
 
14.  It is not possible to effectively monitor all the environmentally-sensitive projects with 
safeguard  review  missions.  To  supplement  the  review  missions,  a  panel  of  environmental 
auditors will be established in each country. The auditors will undertake visits to projects and

4 The environmental service providers may include NGOs, experienced individuals and local consultancies. The 
selection  will be based on a number of criteria including capability and experience of staff, experience in 
environmental management and monitoring and previous training experience.

4   
undertake  an  independent  review  of  how  effectively  the  environmental  management 
requirements are being implemented. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA estimated to cost $ 900,000. ADB will provide $ 800,000 on a grant basis from 
its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF IV) and the participating governments will provide 
the balance as in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are attached as 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  Executing  and  implementing  agencies.  ADB,  through  CWRD's  Gender,  Climate 
Change and Safeguards Unit will be the Executing Agency; and will be responsible for overall 
management  and  coordination.  TA  coordination  will  be  carried  out  by  CWRD's  Senior 
Environment Specialist, assisted by a TA administrator. 
 
17.  Consultants and other input requirements. All consultants will be engaged by ADB in 
accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). The TA will utilize two methods of delivery through (i) individual international consultants, 
and (ii) the recruitment of local firms under an Indefinite Delivery Contract (IDC). Firstly, the 
development of the training program, the training of the trainers and the development of the 
web-based monitoring system will be through consultants recruited on an individual basis. 
Seven person-months of international consulting services have been allocated for these three 
tasks; as it is unlikely that a single consultant will be able to cover all three tasks a number of 
consultants will be recruited. 
 
18.  Secondly, as it is not possible to accurately predict the number of training programs, on 
the job training events and audits that will be required it is intended to deliver these components 
through the Central Operations Services Office (COSO) IDC pilot program. The IDC is the most 
appropriate method of delivery as the services to be delivered under this TA are multiple 
assignments  with  each  component  requiring  the  same  inputs.  Each  contract  will  have  a 
relatively small value of $5,000-$9,000 and so an expensive selection process such as quality- 
and cost-based selection (QCBS) would be inefficient.  
 
19.  Time Frame. The TA will be implemented over three years (July 2010–July 2013). The 
first three months will be allocated to the finalization of the knowledge products and the training 
course and the development of the web based monitoring system. The second three months will 
be devoted to training the trainers and identifying the environmental auditor panels. Delivery of 
the  training  programs  and  on  the  job  training  will  commence  after  six  months  of  the  TA 
implementation. On the completion of the TA, if the approach proves successful, it is expected 
that the costs for training will then be included in the overall project costs. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis for 
Improving the Implementation of Environmental Safeguards in Central and West Asia, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

8   Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultant recruitment for the TA will be undertaken in two phases. The first phase will 
be the recruitment of individual consultants to complete the design of the training course and to 
train the trainers. A software consultant will also be recruited on an individual consultant basis to 
complete  the  software  upgrades  needed  to  develop  the  web-based  tracking  system  for 
environmental management. 
2.  The second phase will be the delivery of the training course, the on the job training and 
third  party  independent  auditing.  These  will  be  given  to  the  executing  and  implementing 
agencies in the various member countries, however it is not possible at this time to predict the 
number and frequency of courses and audits required; therefore this phase of the TA is best 
delivered using the IDC method. 
A.  Training Course Consultant (international, 3 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant recruited to finalize the knowledge products and complete the training 
course  will  have  extensive  experience  in  the  preparation  of  environmental  management 
documents  for  major  construction  projects.  This  must  include  preparation  of  site  specific 
environmental management plans or equivalent, and experience of environmental monitoring for 
major construction projects. 
4.  The training course consultant will: 
 
(i)  work closely with the CWRD's Gender, Climate Change and Safeguards Unit in 
further developing knowledge products which were produced under the SSTA 
Improving  the  Implementation  of  Environmental  Safeguard  Requirements  for 
ADB Projects in Central and West Asia, and 
(ii)  prepare case studies to include in the training course. Edit and improve the 
training course in ADB environmental safeguard requirements to be a stand 
alone document. Organize the translation of the training program into Russian. 
 
B.  Training the Trainers Consultant (international, 3 person-months) 
 
5.  The environmental training consultant will have extensive experience in the delivery of 
training courses to environmental professionals as well as experience in the preparation of 
environmental management plans, environmental monitoring plans and environmental audits. 
6.  The environmental training consultant will: 
 
(i)    familiarize themselves with the training course, 
(ii)  develop an action plan for the identification of suitable consultants or companies 
who can be recruited as trainers, and 
(iii)   undertake training courses to train the trainers. 
 
C.  Information Technology Consultant (international, 1 person-months) 
 
7.  The IT consultant will have extensive experience in the preparation and programming of 
databases and web based query tools. The consultant will: 
 
(i)   prepare  a  database  that  will  function  as  a  document  repository  for  project 
environmental management documents. The database will have a diary/alarm

Appendix 3  9 
function to notify the project leaders and the environment team as to when 
reports are due, and 
(ii)   the database will need to be compatible with existing ADB database systems. 
 
D.  Qualifications and Tasks of Consultants for the Indefinite Delivery Contract  
 
8.  Training Course Consultant/Company 
 
Qualifications: 
(i)  successful completion of the 'Train the Trainers' course by an ADB approved 
trainer, 
(ii)  demonstrated experience in the delivery of environment based training courses, 
(iii)  extensive experience in the environmental assessment of major development 
projects, 
(iv)  extensive experience in the preparation of environmental management plans for 
major construction projects, and 
(v)  extensive experience in environmental monitoring and reporting. 
 
Expected expertise: 
(i)  training specialists with experience in delivering environment based programs, 
(ii)  environment specialists with experience of environmental management, and 
(iii)  environmental  engineers  with  experience  in  supervising  major  construction 
projects. 
 
9.  On The Job Training Consultant/Company 
 
Qualifications: 
(i)  demonstrated  experience  of  environmental  supervision  of  major  construction 
projects,  
(ii)  extensive  experience  in  the  drafting  and  implementation  of  environmental 
management plans, and 
(iii)  extensive experience in undertaking environmental monitoring and reporting. 
 
Expected expertise: 
(i)  environmental scientists or engineers with demonstrated experience of major 
construction projects. 
 
10.  Third Party Auditors 
 
Qualifications: 
(i)  extensive  environmental  auditing  experience  of  a  range  of  processes  and 
projects, 
(ii)  extensive  experience  in  the  drafting  and  implementation  of  environmental 
management plans, and 
(iii)  extensive experience in undertaking environmental monitoring and reporting. 
 
Expected expertise: 
(i)  experienced environmental auditors, preferably with registration to a recognized 
accreditation system.
